title: Regexle SBV reimplementation and benchmarking
notes: SBV prototype served its purpose; mainline solver now uses the direct Z3 backend and active benchmarking work has moved to regexle-haskell-1 and related tasks. Keeping the epic open only if we plan to revive SBV; otherwise consider closing.

title: Add sydtest test suite
description: Set up sydtest-based test suite for the Haskell project and cover Regexle.PuzzleCache functionality.
notes: Added sydtest-based test suite (test-suite spec) with dependencies (sydtest, sydtest-aeson, sydtest-discover, temporary). Implemented PuzzleCacheSpec verifying cache path honors XDG_CACHE_HOME and fetchPuzzle reads cached JSON without network by pre-populating temp cache. cabal test now runs via sydtest-discover.

title: Implement hot-solver path with SBV query mode
description: Goal: reuse a single Z3 session via SBV’s query mode so we avoid re-emitting constraints every puzzle. See docs/hot-solver-sbv-notes.md for current findings (profiling, blocked experiment) and required work (freshVar-based grid rebuild, resetAssertions lifecycle, post-change profiling).

title: Prototype direct Z3 backend
description: Replace SBV with a thin Z3 binding so we can keep solver contexts hot, encode DFAs with native arrays, and avoid SMT-LIB emission. See docs/direct-z3-plan.md for rationale, task breakdown, and open questions.

title: Implement fastest Python method in Haskell solver
Add DFA/lambda caching across clues
Analyze solver stats to target solve-time gap
Improve dead-letter pruning with adaptive positive domains
Document stats workflow (profiles + render script)
Reuse direct Z3 grid across puzzles
notes: Attempted to reuse direct Z3 solver with push/pop, but Z3 4.8.12 crashed (SIGSEGV) when solving multiple puzzles in one context. Rolled back the hot path for now; revisit once we can debug the upstream issue.

title: Enable macro_finder in direct Z3 backend
description: Experiment with Z3 solver parameters/tactics to close the remaining solve-time gap. First lever: turn on macro_finder for the direct backend and re-profile.
notes: Set macro_finder=true via solver params in the direct backend, re-profiled side 3 days 400–409, and shaved solve time to ~14.3 ms (total 0.32 s wall).

title: Review nelhage regex resources
description: Read nelhage-sandbox repo and blog post to extract existing SMT modeling and benchmarking approach for regex crosswords.
notes: Reviewed nelhage-sandbox/regexle sources. Key takeaways: Python solver keeps regex cache, converts via greenery to minimized DFA, then flattens transitions + dead-state analysis for pruning (see third_party/nelhage-sandbox/regexle/src/regexle/main.py:1-520). Multiple matcher strategies exist: FuncMatcher encodes DFA as explicit z3.If ladder, z3.Function, or arrays; EnumMapper vs IntMapper toggles alphabet/state representation. Z3RE fallback uses native z3 regex encoding for comparison. Blog post (Oct 21 2025) documents major speedups from DFA encoding, pruning dead vocab, replacing UFs with explicit transition table, and benchmarking harness scanning regexle puzzles for runtime stats.

title: Investigate Z3 4.15.3 hot-solver crash
description: Hot direct-Z3 path crashes inside Z3_solver_get_model when auto_config=false/random_seed=7/phase_selection=0 are set before solving. Need minimal repro + upstream issue.
notes:
Investigated remaining gap vs Python by dumping DFA stats and experimenting with two alternate encodings. (1) Switching alphabet restrictions from per-letter forbids to allow-lists would drop :added-eqs substantially, but naïve ORs hurt solver performance; (2) an array-of-arrays transition encoding ballooned constraints (~4e7 added eqs) and isn’t viable without deeper tuning. Reverted the branch to the previous lambda-only encoder for now.

Possible next steps:
- Hybrid pruning: keep explicit letter bans only on the first few characters of each clue so early conflicts prune quickly while later positions remain unconstrained.
- Transition sharing: factor per-letter transitions so multiple clues reuse the same ITE builders or explore cached row expressions instead of emitting duplicates.

title: Switch Z3 direct backend to enumeration sorts
Z3 enum hot solver crashes after 5 puzzles
notes: Rebuilt hot solver to allocate fresh state vars per puzzle, eliminating Z3 SIGSEGV; verified 10-day hot profile succeeds.

title: Z3 enum hot solver still crashes for ranges >~5 puzzles
description: Commands such as:\n  cabal run regexle-haskell -- profile --side 3 --days 0..49 --strategy z3 --hot-solver --output /tmp/foo.json\nabort with SIGSEGV/SIGABRT even after the per-clue state var refresh. Running \<=5 puzzles per CLI invocation succeeds, so the 0..409 profile had to be assembled from many 5-day chunks. Need to find the remaining root cause inside Z3/local push-pop reuse.
notes: Captured a two-stage shrink pipeline: stage 1 shrinks JSON params (side/chunk/days) using a SIGSEGV-only test to find the smallest crashing day set (using seeds 7,13,23,37,53); stage 2 captures a dump for that set and shrinks the SMT corpus with the same segfault predicate. Scripts: test_hot_params.py, capture_segfault_dump.sh, capture_and_shrink.sh, double_shrink.sh.

title: Upgrade Haskell Z3 binding to v4.15.x
description: Bring our vendored haskell-z3 binding forward from 408.2 to the newest 4.15-series release so we can test against the version that matches our Linux binaries. Work: find or create an updated binding, update cabal.project/package pins, rebuild regexle-haskell & replay-dump, re-run the shrunk assertion repro for regression. Coordinate with regex-20 since it needs the newer solver.
notes: Upgrade builds and tooling are complete on Z3 4.15.3; hot solver crash (chunk-size 0) remains tracked separately under regex-20 so this task stays focused on the packaging change.

title: Mirror Python enum_func lambda encoding in Haskell Z3 pipeline
notes:
Goal: replicate the fastest Python enum_func lambda encoding in Haskell to shrink :added-eqs and solve time.

Key observations:
- Python path clusters identical DFA columns before building Z3 terms, so each clue emits a short conditional ladder over class reps instead of per-letter gates.
- Our current Haskell direct backend never precomputes those classes; attempts to synthesize them on the fly blown up constraints (large ORs or char_class UFs).
- Need to push the clustering earlier (probably alongside Regexle.DFA) and feed the grouped structure into transitionLambda so reuse falls out naturally.

Open questions:
- Where to store class signatures so hot solver reuse works (probably extend DfaInfo).
- How to share per-class predicates across clues without refcount leaks/duplication.
- How to keep algebraic sorts while matching Python’s Int-based approach.

Benchmark target: hit or beat Python enum_func lambda stats on side-3 days 400..409.

title: Precompute DFA column classes for reuse
Rewrite transitionLambda to reuse clustered columns
Benchmark clustered encoding vs python enum_func lambda
Specialize direct Z3 state enums per clue
notes: 2025-11-01: Prototyped per-clue state datatypes to mirror Python’s class clustering. Lambda hot path saw :added-eqs drop (~51.9k→44.6k) but direct enum hot regressed badly. Hybrid attempt (global enum + small locals) didn’t recover the win, so we rolled back to the single shared StateSort.

title: Add nelhage-sandbox submodule
description: Add https://github.com/nelhage/nelhage-sandbox as a git submodule in the repo to reuse benchmark assets.
notes: Added git submodule at third_party/nelhage-sandbox for benchmark assets.

title: Restore enum_hot performance after per-clue state domains
notes: 2025-11-01: Re-ran enum_hot after per-clue enums; still regressed, even with small-state special cases. Conclusion: stay with original single StateSort for hot enum backend.

title: Reproduce 6ms enum_hot benchmark with Z3 4.15.3
notes: Benchmarks were picking up system Z3 4.8.12. Added helper scripts to confirm version (scripts/print_z3_version.hs, scripts/dump_state_counts.hs, scripts/dump_dead_alphabet.hs) and reran hot profile with vendor 4.15.3 via "LD_LIBRARY_PATH=z3-415.3/vendor/z3-4.15.3/bin cabal exec -- regexle-haskell profile ...". New stats captured in stats/profile-z3-enum-hot-400-409-ldpath2.json (avg build ~9.6ms, solve ~13.0ms). Need follow-up to explain remaining gap vs 6ms target.

title: Implement pyclone solver that mimics Python enum_func behavior
notes: Added per-cell dedupe so overlapping clues only assert new alphabet bans once. Day 510 still sits ~2.3k :added-eqs (avg 2.7k across 510-519); dedupe primarily prevents reasserting the same inequalities when clues share a cell but doesn’t yet close the gap to Python (~70). Next steps live under regex-33 for richer sharing.

title: Deduplicate repeated PyClone cell/state exclusions
notes: Shifted PyClone to integer domains and reuse DFA column classes when building lambda transitions; now per-cell alph/state ranges are simple bounds and day-510 profile drops :mk-bool-var from 793 to 12 with :added-eqs largely eliminated.

title: Switch PyClone bans to mkEq/mkNot instead of distinct
Rebuild PyClone transition lambda to match Python ITE ladder
Stop routing PyClone constraints through Z3.Goal
Ensure Kleene DFA pipeline matches greenery.reduce()
Select Haskell FSM library
description: Survey Haskell libraries that can replace greenery for DFA/NFA manipulation, evaluating suitability for regex crossword solving.
notes: HaLeX: regex parser + NDFA/DFA pipeline with minimization and GraphViz export (Main.DFA, Main.RegExp modules), but last upload 1.2.6 in 2017 targeting GHC 6.8—expect patching before integrating. kleene: derivative-based regex compiler that returns minimized DFAs with explicit transition lookup, works for any Ord alphabet, exposes helpers like dfaBlackholes for dead states and toDot for visualization, and maps regex literals to AST via compile. Likely starting point for SBV integration: use kleene for DFA + pruning data, optionally borrow HaLeX minimizer if kleene gaps appear.

title: Outline SBV-based solver
description: Draft design for regexle solver using the Haskell SBV library, including data flow, constraint encoding, and integration points with benchmarks.
notes: Drafted SBV solver outline in docs/sbv-solver-outline.md covering DFA generation with kleene, SBV grid/state encoding, dead-state pruning, and benchmark integration hooks.

title: Plan cross-language benchmarks
description: Define benchmarking strategy comparing Python regexle, Haskell SBV implementation, and alternative Haskell approaches, leveraging nelhage-sandbox scripts.

title: Port nelhage puzzle fetch + cache
description: Adapt Nelson's puzzle retrieval and local caching logic (regexle API + ~/.cache layout) for reuse in the Haskell benchmarking workflow.
notes: Added cabal project scaffolding with library module Regexle.PuzzleCache exposing cacheRoot/puzzleCachePath/fetchPuzzle. Implementation mirrors Python flow: uses XDG cache (~/.cache/regexle), decodes cached JSON when present, otherwise fetches https://generator.regexle.com/api via http-client, validates HTTP 200, stores body, and parses puzzle schema. Executable now fetches day/side args and prints JSON.

title: Implement DFA pruning constraints
description: Ensure SBV solver enforces dead-state and dead-vocab pruning analogous to Nelson's numpy analysis for faster solving.
notes: Implemented SBV-based solver using kleene DFA transitions with dead-state pruning (src/Regexle/Solver.hs). Added regex parser (Regexle.RegexParser) translating puzzle regex to Kleene ERE. CLI matrix/profile now run the solver: matrix records build/solve times, solution grid, or error if Z3 missing; profile aggregates solved count and averages. Tested with Z3 4.8.12 (Ubuntu package) producing solutions for days 400-402.

title: Port benchmark matrix to Haskell
description: Translate Nelson's profile/matrix benchmarking harness into Haskell to run comparisons across solver strategies.
notes: Matrix/profile commands now wired to SBV solver. With Z3 installed (4.8.12), matrix side=3 days 400-402 solved puzzles in ~1.0-1.9s build, 0.07-0.13s solve; profile summarized 3/3 solved with avg build 1.53s, solve 0.106s.

title: Plan cross-language benchmarks
description: Define benchmarking strategy comparing Python regexle, Haskell SBV implementation, and alternative Haskell approaches, leveraging nelhage-sandbox scripts.

title: Regexle SBV reimplementation and benchmarking
Switch third-party git submodule to HTTPS URL
Document Codex Cloud environment setup
Enable Cachix for Nix builds
notes: Swapped CI to build/test entirely via nix flake checks (GHC 9.12) and wired Attic pull/push commands plus Makefile helpers so local runs mirror CI. Range-set-list patched via overlay to lift base/hashable bounds. Attic uploads can hit 502s on huge closures—current cache warm but monitor server if CI falls back to rebuilding.

title: Fix nix build for default package
Measure warm cache build performance
Trigger PR #3 CI for cache validation
Investigate CI cache misses & Attic auth warning
